headline.main: Wealthy and Stable Venezuela Luring Many Latin Immigrants

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, June 13  Rumors have always played an important role in Argentine politics, and yesterday provided an illustration of how wild, unconfirmed reports can rage through this capital among politicians, diplomats, journalists, businessmen and...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, June 13 Rumors have always played an important role in Argentine politics, and yesterday provided an illustration of how wild, unconfirmed reports can rage through this capital among politicians, diplomats, journalists, businessmen and ordinary citizens.
docs.abstract: history of an untrue rumor in Argentina, that Social Welfare Min Jose Lopez Rega was arrested while trying to leave country, recounted to illustrate crisis atmosphere in country; Lopez Rega illus (M)

headline.main: A Classic Day for Argentine Rumor Mill

byline.original: By JONATHAN KANDELL Special to The York Times

docs.snippet: Names and titles don't mean a thing in the Onaasis organization if indeed organization is the proper ward for a maze of corporations and trusts designed in large part to mask the identity of the owner.

docs.abstract: article on how late Aristotle Onassis ran his business empire; Onassis's closest advisers included Constantine Konialidis, Nicholas Cokkinis, Stylianos Papadimitriou, Michael Dologlou, Costas Gratsos and Prof John Georgakis; illus of Papadimitriou, Georgakis, Cokkinis and Konialidis (M)

keywords.value: OFFICE BUILDINGS AND OTHER COMMERCIAL PROPERTIES

docs.snippet: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 17 (Reuters)--Mark Farrell, a powerful, 22-yearold left-handed Briton, upset Stan Smith of the United States, 9-8, 9-8, today in the second round of the $108,000 John Player grass tennis tournament.
docs.lead_paragraph: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 17 (Reuters)--Mark Farrell, a powerful, 22-yearold left-handed Briton, upset Stan Smith of the United States, 9-8, 9-8, today in the second round of the $108,000 John Player grass tennis tournament.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 28-- White House officials under President Kennedy made an abortive, last-minute attempt to stop the assassination of the Dominican Republic dictator, General Rafael Trujillo Molina, according to former intelligence officers and...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 28-- White House officials under President Kennedy made an abortive, last-minute attempt to stop the assassination of the Dominican Republic dictator, General Rafael Trujillo Molina, according to former intelligence officers and current Government sources.
docs.abstract: Natl Security Council under former Pres Kennedy reptdly made abortive effort on May 29 '61 to stop assassination of Dominican Repub dictator Gen Rafael Trujillo Molina; cable was reptdly sent to CIA chief in Dominican Republic, but it did not prevent assassination, reptdly because CIA was only giving material support to dissident groups and never controlled plotting; Kennedy Adm is said to have opposed any violent action in Dominican Repub unless it would lead to formation of new, stable govt favorable to US; Rockefeller Comm has substantial part of record of CIA involvement in Trujillo's death and has made it available to Sen Select Com on Intelligence; repts differ on exact nature of US support for Trujillo's overthrow; Dominican Brig Gen Antonio Imbert Barreras, only survivor of group that actually killed Trujillo, says CIA had no role whatsoever; Philip Agee says agency passed guns to Cuban assassins through US agent; assassins, however, were Dominicans; Lorenzo D Berry, who is said to have been US agent in Dominican Repub, denies involvement in plot (M)

headline.main: President Kennedy Is Said to Have Tried to Stop Assassination of Trujillo

byline.original: By NICHOLAS M. HORROCK Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France In a strange combination of causes and terrors, activist European minority groups held a secret meeting in Trieste last year, according to members of the Basque militant organization.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France In a strange combination of causes and terrors, activist European minority groups held a secret meeting in Trieste last year, according to members of the Basque militant organization.
docs.abstract: Members of Basque militant orgn rept activist W Eur minority groups held secret meeting in Trieste in '74 to discuss their shared sense of ethnic oppression and demands for autonomy; common aim was 'a Eur of peoples' (L)

headline.main: Western Europe's Militant Minorities Find Common Cause in Secret Meeting

byline.original: By FLORA LEWIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 7 (AP) Douglas Palm of Sweden eliminated Fred McNair of Chevy Chase, Md., 6-2, 6-2, in the first round of the $50,000 Swedish open tennis championships today.

docs.snippet: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 11 (AP) Thomas Koch, the 30-year-old Brazilian tennis star, whipped top-seeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden, 6-2, 6-3, today in quarterfinal round of the $50,000 Swedish open Championships. It was the first major upset of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 11 (AP) Thomas Koch, the 30-year-old Brazilian tennis star, whipped top-seeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden, 6-2, 6-3, today in quarterfinal round of the $50,000 Swedish open Championships. It was the first major upset of the tournament.

headline.main: Borg Put To Rout By Koch
